<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp090" view="all">Projection along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, showing the three interpenetrating lattices in different colors (green, purple, and yellow) in pseudo-layers seen down the Cu<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Cu direction. elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0025">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp035" view="all">Illustration of the BF4<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion of compound (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) involved in anion–π interactions with triazole rings (red and green dotted lines) and in hydrogen bonds (purple dotted lines). These non-covalent interactions are characterized by the distances F5⋯C5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.11(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; F6⋯C6s<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.052(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; F6⋯N4s<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.909(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; F3⋯C5s<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.137(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and O1−H1⋯F5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.725(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (the angle O1−H1−F5 is 168(3)°). Symmetry operation: <ce:italic>s</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, ¼<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, ¼<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  Illustration of the BF4- anion of compound (1) involved in anion-π interactions with triazole rings (red and green dotted lines) and in hydrogen bonds (purple dotted lines). These non-covalent interactions are characterized by the distances F5⋯C5=3.11(2)Å; F6⋯C6s=3.052(13)Å; F6⋯N4s=2.909(13)Å; F3⋯C5s=3.137(6)Å and O1-H1⋯F5=2.725(8)Å (the angle O1-H1-F5 is 168(3)°). Symmetry operation: s =1- x, ¼+ y, ¼+ z (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article).

</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Research highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp010" view="all">► The ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1yl)butane acts as a bidentate bridging ligand. ► Cu(II) is bridged by 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1yl)butane forming coordination networks. ► A 2-D coordination network solid is formed with chloride as coordination anion. ► 3-D coordination network solids are formed with non-coordinating anions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1yl)butane acts as a bidentate ligand, bridging copper(II) ions, generating coordination polymers in network structures.     

Research highlights

► The ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1yl)butane acts as a bidentate bridging ligand. ► Cu(II) is bridged by 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1yl)butane forming coordination networks. ► A 2-D coordination network solid is formed with chloride as coordination anion. ► 3-D coordination network solids are formed with non-coordinating anions.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp015" view="all">The coordination chemistry of three selected copper(II) salts with the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (abbreviated as <ce:bold>btb</ce:bold>) is described. This ligand acts as a bidentate ligand, bridging copper(II) ions, thereby generating polymers in 2D and 3D network solids.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The coordination chemistry of three selected copper(II) salts with the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (abbreviated as btb) is described. This ligand acts as a bidentate ligand, bridging copper(II) ions, thereby generating polymers in 2D and 3D network solids.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Coordination network solids, some of them also known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are based upon self-assembly between metal ions (mostly transition-metal ions) and dinucleating (or polynucleating) organic ligands. This self-assembly is influenced by several factors, like solvent systems, temperature, metal ions and used counterions as pioneered by Robson, Kitagawa and Yaghi , and followed by many others . The length and shape of the organic ligand has, of course, an influence on the coordination geometry of the metal ion and the whole structure in general. In the literature, a wide variety of flexible ligands with the general formula L-(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>-L (in which L is a heterocyclic nitrogen donor ligand) have been reported, such as bis(benzotriazol-1-yl)alkanes , bis(imidazol-1-yl)alkanes , bis(benzimidazol-1-yl)-alkanes  and bis(4-pyridyl)alkanes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination network solids, some of them also known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are based upon self-assembly between metal ions (mostly transition-metal ions) and dinucleating (or polynucleating) organic ligands. This self-assembly is influenced by several factors, like solvent systems, temperature, metal ions and used counterions as pioneered by Robson, Kitagawa and Yaghi , and followed by many others . The length and shape of the organic ligand has, of course, an influence on the coordination geometry of the metal ion and the whole structure in general. In the literature, a wide variety of flexible ligands with the general formula L-(CH2) n -L (in which L is a heterocyclic nitrogen donor ligand) have been reported, such as bis(benzotriazol-1-yl)alkanes , bis(imidazol-1-yl)alkanes , bis(benzimidazol-1-yl)-alkanes  and bis(4-pyridyl)alkanes .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In an earlier research from this laboratory bridging substituted triazoles have been used , whereas more recently the coordination chemistry of several bis(1,2,4-triazole-1-yl)alkanes has been investigated through the synthesis of copper(II) and iron(II) compounds .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In an earlier research from this laboratory bridging substituted triazoles have been used , whereas more recently the coordination chemistry of several bis(1,2,4-triazole-1-yl)alkanes has been investigated through the synthesis of copper(II) and iron(II) compounds .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">With the ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1yl)butane (abbreviated as <ce:bold>btb</ce:bold>; see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>), to the best of our knowledge, only a limited number of X-ray crystal structures is known with <ce:bold>btb</ce:bold> as the only ligand and transition metals; hence, polymeric compounds with hexacoordinated Mn(II) , Fe(II) , Zn(II) , Co(II) and Cd(II)  nodes have been described. Remarkably, X-ray structures of Cu(II)/<ce:bold>btb</ce:bold> systems are lacking so far. This may be explained by the fact that Cu(II) rarely takes six identical donor atoms of the same type, so that the generation of 3D structures with this metal ion is less favored.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: With the ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1yl)butane (abbreviated as btb; see  ), to the best of our knowledge, only a limited number of X-ray crystal structures is known with btb as the only ligand and transition metals; hence, polymeric compounds with hexacoordinated Mn(II) , Fe(II) , Zn(II) , Co(II) and Cd(II)  nodes have been described. Remarkably, X-ray structures of Cu(II)/btb systems are lacking so far. This may be explained by the fact that Cu(II) rarely takes six identical donor atoms of the same type, so that the generation of 3D structures with this metal ion is less favored.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Therefore, we have studied the possible formation of network coordination compounds with Cu(II). Herein, we report the synthesis of three new copper(II) compounds with different anions, i.e. [Cu(<ce:bold>btb</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>(BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cu(<ce:bold>btb</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>btb</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). Their single-crystal X-ray structures, physical and electronic properties are described and the differences with the Cd analogs are discussed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Therefore, we have studied the possible formation of network coordination compounds with Cu(II). Herein, we report the synthesis of three new copper(II) compounds with different anions, i.e. [Cu(btb)2(H2O)2] n (BF4)2  n  (1), [Cu(btb)2(H2O)2] n (NO3)2  n  (2) and [CuCl2(btb)2] n  (3). Their single-crystal X-ray structures, physical and electronic properties are described and the differences with the Cd analogs are discussed.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">C, H, N determinations were performed on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 Series II analyzer. Ligand-field spectra were obtained on a Perkin–Elmer Lambda900 spectrophotometer, using the diffuse reflectance technique, with MgO as a reference. EPR spectra were recorded on a Bruker-EMX<ce:italic>plus</ce:italic> electron spin resonance spectrometer (field calibrated with DPPH (<ce:italic>g</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.0036)). FTIR spectra were obtained on a Perkin–Elmer Paragon 1000 FTIR spectrophotometer equipped with a Golden Gate ATR device, using the reflectance technique (4000–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, res. 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General

C, H, N determinations were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Series II analyzer. Ligand-field spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda900 spectrophotometer, using the diffuse reflectance technique, with MgO as a reference. EPR spectra were recorded on a Bruker-EMXplus electron spin resonance spectrometer (field calibrated with DPPH (g =2.0036)). FTIR spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer Paragon 1000 FTIR spectrophotometer equipped with a Golden Gate ATR device, using the reflectance technique (4000-300cm-1, res. 4cm-1).

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of the ligand</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The ligand was synthesized according to a procedure described earlier . All other chemicals were commercially available and used without purification.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Synthesis of the coordination compounds</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The compounds were prepared following the present general procedure: 1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol of the copper(II) salt (Cu(BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, (Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and 1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol of the ligand were each dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of water. The copper(II) salt solution was subsequently added slowly to the ligand solution and the resulting mixture was filtered to remove any non-dissolved material. After a few days to a week the products separated as very small crystals. The yield for all three compounds is in the range 70–80%. Elemental analysis: <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>B<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuF<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): C, 29.2; H, 4.3; N, 25.6. Found: C, 29.1; H, 4.2; N, 25.6%. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>): C, 31.6; H, 4.6; N, 32.2. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthesis of the ligand

The ligand was synthesized according to a procedure described earlier . All other chemicals were commercially available and used without purification.

Synthesis of the coordination compounds

The compounds were prepared following the present general procedure: 1.2mmol of the copper(II) salt (Cu(BF4)2(H2O)6, (Cu(NO3)2(H2O)3 or CuCl2(H2O)2) and 1.2mmol of the ligand were each dissolved in 10ml of water. The copper(II) salt solution was subsequently added slowly to the ligand solution and the resulting mixture was filtered to remove any non-dissolved material. After a few days to a week the products separated as very small crystals. The yield for all three compounds is in the range 70-80%. Elemental analysis: Anal. Calc. for C16H28B2CuF8N12O2 (1): C, 29.2; H, 4.3; N, 25.6. Found: C, 29.1; H, 4.2; N, 25.6%. Anal. Calc. for C16H28CuN14O8 (2): C, 31.6; H, 4.6; N, 32.2. Found: C, 31.5; H, 4.6; N, 32.3%. Anal. Calc. for C16H24Cl2CuN12 (3): C, 37.0; H, 4.7; N, 32.4. Found: C, 36.9; H: 4.6; N, 32.4%.

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination and refinement

For compounds 1 and 2: for each coordination compound a suitable single crystal was selected from the mother liquor and mounted to a glass fiber using the oil-drop method . Diffraction data were collected on a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer (graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation). The structures were solved by direct methods. The programs collect , shelxs-97 , shelxl-97  were used for data reduction, structure solution and structure refinement, respectively. Refinement on F 2 was performed against all reflections. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Details for (1): the C7 carbon atom and the tetrafluoridoborate anion were disordered. The H atoms of the coordinating water ligand were determined in a difference map and refined with esd's riding with the O atom. All other H atoms were geometrically fixed and allowed to ride on the attached atoms. Details for (2): the C7 carbon atom and the nitrate anion were disordered. The H atoms of the coordinating water ligand were determined in a difference map and refined with esd's riding with the O atom. All other H atoms were geometrically fixed and allowed to ride on the attached atoms.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of the crystal structures of 1 and 2 

Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural (i.e., have the same molecular structure) and isomorphous (have the same space group); therefore they will be discussed together. They crystallise in the orthorhombic space group Fddd and both consist of a [Cu(btb)2(H2O)2]2- cationic part and two (BF4)- (for 1) and two (NO3)- (for 2) anions. The anions are disordered in the lattice; also the alkyl C7 atom appears as disordered. A thermal ellipsoid plot, together with the numbering scheme is presented in   (for 1) and in  (for 2), while selected bond distances and angles are listed in  . The copper(II) ion is tetragonally coordinated, with each Cu ion surrounded by four N atoms belonging to four different (bridging) btb ligands, with a CuN distance of 2.012(2)Ǻ (for 1) and of 2.011(2)Ǻ (for 2). The axial positions are occupied by coordinating water molecules with CuO distances of 2.415(2)Ǻ (for 1) and of 2.407(2)Ǻ (for 2). The btb ligands are bridging the copper(II) atoms to form a complicated polymeric architecture with uninodal tetrahedral 4-connected 3D-diamond net, with short-hand symbol 66, as has been reported before by Ding et al. for a related and isomorphous (same formula and space group) Cd(II) BF4 - compound , see also  in that paper. The differences in the cell axes between the Cu(II) and the Cd(II) correlate with shorter M-N distances for Cu, and a longer M-H2O distance for Cu. Projections using TOPOS software  are presented in   . Another projection of this interpenetration is given in . Compound 2 has a different space group and composition compared with the Cd nitrato compound .

<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, a hydrogen-bonding interaction is observed between the water oxygen atom and a fluoride of the disordered BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> molecule, with a O⋯F distance of 2.725(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ǻ (angle 168(3)°; see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> a hydrogen-bonding interaction is observed between the water oxygen atom and an oxygen atom of the disordered NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> molecule, with a O⋯O distance of 2.765(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ǻ (angle 164(4)°). The disordered anions are involved in anion–π interactions  with neighboring triazole rings. For instance for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the fluoride atom F3 is in close contact with the triazole carbon atom C5s (). This supramolecular interaction is characterized by a ring centroid⋯F3 distance of 3.444(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which indicates a weak anion–π association . Similarly, the atom F6 interacts with the triazole atoms N4s and C5s (). The ring centroid⋯F6 distance is 3.278(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, thus characterizing a moderate interaction . In the same way, the nitrate anions in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> experience anion–π interactions with electron-deficient triazole moieties. No ring-ring stacking is observed.</ce:para>

Similarly, the atom F6 interacts with the triazole atoms N4s and C5s (). The ring centroid⋯F6 distance is 3.278(5)Å, thus characterizing a moderate interaction . In the same way, the nitrate anions in 2 experience anion-π interactions with electron-deficient triazole moieties. No ring-ring stacking is observed.

Description of the crystal structure of compound 3 

A thermal ellipsoid plot of compound (3), which crystallizes in the space group P21/c (No. 14), together with the numbering scheme, is presented in  , and selected bond distances and angles are listed in . The copper(II) ion is tetragonally surrounded by four N atoms belonging to four different (bridging) btb ligands, with Cu-N distances of 2.010(2) and 2.036(2)Ǻ. The two axial positions are occupied by chloride anions with CuCl distances of 2.7994(6)Ǻ. The btb ligands are bridging the copper(II) atoms to form a distorted (4,4) 2D grid ( ). elements.clean_text:
Infrared spectroscopy, ligand field and EPR

The IR spectra of the three compounds in the region 1750-300cm-1 are given as . In the IR spectra, the water vibrations of the coordinated water molecules in compounds 1 and 2 are clearly visible. The ν as(OH) ν s(OH) are observed at 3592, 3529cm-1 (compound 1) and as a broad band with a center at around 3402cm-1 (compound 2). In both compounds, the δ sOH is observed at 1634cm-1 (for 1) and at 1640cm-1 (for 2). These bands are absent in the IR spectrum of 3. For the coordinated water molecules, also the wagging en rocking vibrations can be observed in the range 700-600cm-1 and the M-O vibrations around 450cm-1 . The first region is not so clear in both compounds, due to the strong ligand vibrations, but the M-O vibrations for compounds 1 and 2 are observed as a very broad band at ca. 450cm-1 (for 1) and at around 550cm-1 (for 2), which is confirming the observations described in the literature . The vibrations of the anions in compounds 1 and 2 are observed at 1058/1028cm-1 (BF4 -) and at 1332cm-1 (NO3 -), which is in agreement with literature data .

In  , the data of the ligand field and EPR measurements are shown.

The ligand-field transitions measured as a solid with the diffuse reflectance technique are observed for all four compounds as broad band with a maximum from 15.5 to 16.5×103 cm-1 with a shoulder at 10.2 to 11.8×103 cm-1. These bands are in agreement with the distorted octahedral geometry for all four compounds .

elements.clean_text: The powder EPR spectra of all three compounds reveal at RT a broad isotropic band due to S =½ (around g =2.10), with a weak axial signal (g perp =2.06-2.07 and g // =2.27-2.40). These signals indicate a d x2-y2 configuration for the ground state . elements.content: <ce:section-title>Concluding remarks</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Three new copper(II) polynuclear coordination compounds with bridging triazole-based ligands and three different anions are reported. The 3D structures have been determined for all three compounds, showing the triazole ligands to be bridging between copper ions, in such a way that each Cu is coordinated by four different ligand molecules in an equatorial plane. The Cu coordination is completed by two weaker <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> axial ligands (anion, or water). The flexibility of the ligands does not result in cavities as seen in related ligands with a more rigid structure. However, in compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, an interpenetrating tetrahedral 4-connected 3D-dia-net, with short-hand symbol 6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> is observed, as for the analogous and isomorphous Cd(II) compound . Spectroscopic results (IR, LF, and EPR) do not exhibit any unusual non-molecular features. The electronic properties of Cu(II), with preference for a tetragonal geometry, clearly do not allow the formation of a regular 3D network, as has been observed for e.g., Mn, Fe and Zn .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Concluding remarks

Three new copper(II) polynuclear coordination compounds with bridging triazole-based ligands and three different anions are reported. The 3D structures have been determined for all three compounds, showing the triazole ligands to be bridging between copper ions, in such a way that each Cu is coordinated by four different ligand molecules in an equatorial plane. The Cu coordination is completed by two weaker trans axial ligands (anion, or water). The flexibility of the ligands does not result in cavities as seen in related ligands with a more rigid structure. However, in compounds 1 and 2, an interpenetrating tetrahedral 4-connected 3D-dia-net, with short-hand symbol 66 is observed, as for the analogous and isomorphous Cd(II) compound . Spectroscopic results (IR, LF, and EPR) do not exhibit any unusual non-molecular features. The electronic properties of Cu(II), with preference for a tetragonal geometry, clearly do not allow the formation of a regular 3D network, as has been observed for e.g., Mn, Fe and Zn .

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthesis of the ligand

The ligand was synthesized according to a procedure described earlier . All other chemicals were commercially available and used without purification.

Synthesis of the coordination compounds

The compounds were prepared following the present general procedure: 1.2mmol of the copper(II) salt (Cu(BF4)2(H2O)6, (Cu(NO3)2(H2O)3 or CuCl2(H2O)2) and 1.2mmol of the ligand were each dissolved in 10ml of water. The copper(II) salt solution was subsequently added slowly to the ligand solution and the resulting mixture was filtered to remove any non-dissolved material. After a few days to a week the products separated as very small crystals. The yield for all three compounds is in the range 70-80%. Elemental analysis: Anal. Calc. for C16H28B2CuF8N12O2 (1): C, 29.2; H, 4.3; N, 25.6. Found: C, 29.1; H, 4.2; N, 25.6%. Anal. Calc. for C16H28CuN14O8 (2): C, 31.6; H, 4.6; N, 32.2. Found: C, 31.5; H, 4.6; N, 32.3%. Anal. Calc. for C16H24Cl2CuN12 (3): C, 37.0; H, 4.7; N, 32.4. Found: C, 36.9; H: 4.6; N, 32.4%.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of the crystal structures of 1 and 2 

Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural (i.e., have the same molecular structure) and isomorphous (have the same space group); therefore they will be discussed together. They crystallise in the orthorhombic space group Fddd and both consist of a [Cu(btb)2(H2O)2]2- cationic part and two (BF4)- (for 1) and two (NO3)- (for 2) anions. The anions are disordered in the lattice; also the alkyl C7 atom appears as disordered. A thermal ellipsoid plot, together with the numbering scheme is presented in   (for 1) and in  (for 2), while selected bond distances and angles are listed in  . The copper(II) ion is tetragonally coordinated, with each Cu ion surrounded by four N atoms belonging to four different (bridging) btb ligands, with a CuN distance of 2.012(2)Ǻ (for 1) and of 2.011(2)Ǻ (for 2). The axial positions are occupied by coordinating water molecules with CuO distances of 2.415(2)Ǻ (for 1) and of 2.407(2)Ǻ (for 2). The btb ligands are bridging the copper(II) atoms to form a complicated polymeric architecture with uninodal tetrahedral 4-connected 3D-diamond net, with short-hand symbol 66, as has been reported before by Ding et al. for a related and isomorphous (same formula and space group) Cd(II) BF4 - compound , see also  in that paper. The differences in the cell axes between the Cu(II) and the Cd(II) correlate with shorter M-N distances for Cu, and a longer M-H2O distance for Cu. Projections using TOPOS software  are presented in   . Another projection of this interpenetration is given in . Compound 2 has a different space group and composition compared with the Cd nitrato compound .

Description of the crystal structure of compound 3 

A thermal ellipsoid plot of compound (3), which crystallizes in the space group P21/c (No. 14), together with the numbering scheme, is presented in  , and selected bond distances and angles are listed in . The copper(II) ion is tetragonally surrounded by four N atoms belonging to four different (bridging) btb ligands, with Cu-N distances of 2.010(2) and 2.036(2)Ǻ. The two axial positions are occupied by chloride anions with CuCl distances of 2.7994(6)Ǻ. The btb ligands are bridging the copper(II) atoms to form a distorted (4,4) 2D grid ( ). The lattice is stabilized by stacking interactions between the triazole rings, characterized by a ring-ring distance of 3.762Ǻ.  shows a packing detail.

Infrared spectroscopy, ligand field and EPR

The IR spectra of the three compounds in the region 1750-300cm-1 are given as . In the IR spectra, the water vibrations of the coordinated water molecules in compounds 1 and 2 are clearly visible. The ν as(OH) ν s(OH) are observed at 3592, 3529cm-1 (compound 1) and as a broad band with a center at around 3402cm-1 (compound 2). In both compounds, the δ sOH is observed at 1634cm-1 (for 1) and at 1640cm-1 (for 2). These bands are absent in the IR spectrum of 3. For the coordinated water molecules, also the wagging en rocking vibrations can be observed in the range 700-600cm-1 and the M-O vibrations around 450cm-1 . The first region is not so clear in both compounds, due to the strong ligand vibrations, but the M-O vibrations for compounds 1 and 2 are observed as a very broad band at ca. 450cm-1 (for 1) and at around 550cm-1 (for 2), which is confirming the observations described in the literature . The vibrations of the anions in compounds 1 and 2 are observed at 1058/1028cm-1 (BF4 -) and at 1332cm-1 (NO3 -), which is in agreement with literature data .

In  , the data of the ligand field and EPR measurements are shown.

The ligand-field transitions measured as a solid with the diffuse reflectance technique are observed for all four compounds as broad band with a maximum from 15.5 to 16.5×103 cm-1 with a shoulder at 10.2 to 11.8×103 cm-1. These bands are in agreement with the distorted octahedral geometry for all four compounds .

The powder EPR spectra of all three compounds reveal at RT a broad isotropic band due to S =½ (around g =2.10), with a weak axial signal (g perp =2.06-2.07 and g // =2.27-2.40). These signals indicate a d x2-y2 configuration for the ground state . Given the long CuCu distances in all compounds, magnetic susceptibility studies were not expected to be relevant, and very low-T studies were not performed.
